results.title: Extending boundaries
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Merna Curnow, raised on a farm, always wanted to be a teacher. She never considered herself as a farmer, not even when she married a third generation farmer of the Curnow family. Teacher, mother and supportive wife until one day she suffered an identity crisis when helping her husband out on the farm. That day became a turning point in Merna’s life.

results.title: I've been everywhere
results.creator_credit: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Robert Flisher was excited to leave Australia and see the world as it was his childhood dream to join the Navy. Flisher opens up about his experiences with the Navy and talks about some of the exciting places he visited during his service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Trade routes
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Professor Eric Willmot describes the ancient trade routes set up by the Aborigines all over the continent, the evidence for their existence and the effect they had on the structure of Aboriginal society. 100,000 years ago the first people came to Australia. A thriving trade in stone age technology, and in red ochre began. The law of ancient Australia, of beholdenness, and all its implications, still followed by tribal Aborigines today, was derived from this trade. But the trade routes also carried destruction in the form of disease and white settlers. Yet many are still used, albeit using different methods of transport and trading new commodities.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: We kept them flying
results.creator_credit: Maude Coates, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: On the way home from enrolling in the Women’s Australian Auxiliary Air Force (WAAAF) in 1941, Maude Coates learnt that the Japanese forces had just bombed Darwin. For almost 4 years, Coates worked hard and built a great sense of companionship with the other women she lived and worked with. Serving time in the Women’s Forces out of duty, Maude feels proud to have served her country and been part of history.

results.title: Rainbow serpent
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: Presents the cultural heritage of the first Australians through their own eyes. In an unbiased, unpatronising light it paints a realistic picture of a society whose tarnished image was created by those who supposedly made this country - the European settlers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Survivors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
This program, narrated by Aboriginal playwright and actor, Bob Maza, concentrates on the attempts by the 4000 strong Tasmanian Aboriginal community to reveal that Truganini was not the last of the Tasmanian Aborigines, and in doing so, to re-establish their pride and identity in contemporary Tasmanian society. These attempts include the production of the first play by and about Tasmanian Aborigines - “We are the Survivors”, by Jim Everett, and the campaign by Aboriginal activist and barrister, Michael Mansell, to reclaim the remains of Tasmanian Aborigines stored in the Anatomy Department of the University of Edinburgh.

results.title: A Chance to travel
results.creator_credit: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When George Snowden joined the Australian army, he was given the opportunity to tour Australia. Despite being given the chance to travel across the country, Snowden ended up suffering from a knee injury and was happy to return home after seeing most of the country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Women: three views
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Interviews with three Aboriginal women who have chosen to be activists in the struggle for their peoples’ rights. Mum Shirl has been an activist since the late sixties, including initiating the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in the early seventies. Since then she has become disillusioned with political processes in Australia and now chooses to work directly with Aboriginal people in prisons. Marcia Langton works for the Central Lands Council in Alice Springs and she talks passionately on behalf of Aboriginal peoples’ struggles for land rights and dignity. Maryanne Bin-Sallik works within government departments using established political means to argue for the rights of Aborigines. Though choosing very different ways to express their activism, we see that all three women are united in their commitment to work towards an autonomous and central role for Aborigines in Australian politics and culture.
